Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you stands a regal woman in golden dress and fine silks, fingers heavy with rings. Her eyes flicker with appraisal as she closes an ornate ledger.

"You stand in the Gilded Hall, where Sunreach's fortunes are weighed—and, if you can afford it, multiplied. I am Nalia, master of the Merchant Guild and keeper of every honest (and less-than-honest) coin that passes these gates.

Tell me: are you here to deposit, withdraw, or... invest in something more *lucrative*?"

Option.text: Are all fortunes truly made here?
What services does the Merchant Guild offer?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Nalia’s lips curl in a faint smile.

"Fortune is made wherever people want more than they can earn, and lose more than they can afford. But yes—Sunreach makes fortunes, breaks them, and sells them back to their original owners for a fee.
My advice? Never trust a smiling merchant. Especially not in this city."

Option.text: I want in on these fortunes.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She lowers her voice.

"Five Houses squabble for control; pirates, princes, and scholars all believe they rule. But gold is the only authority Sunreach truly respects.
I run the Guild. The Guild moves the coin. Coin moves the city. Remember that."

"Banking, exchange, loans, investments—if it touches coin, it passes through my ledgers. Of course, not every transaction is... for public record.
If you have gold to hide, debts to erase, or enemies to ruin, the Gilded Coin offers creative solutions. Discretion costs extra."

"Every guildmaster has rivals: Darius wants my ledgers, Seraphine wants my vaults, and Magistrate Thornwall wants plausible deniability.
Minax's cultists want everything. But gold buys silence, loyalty—or at least, enough time to plan your next move."

Option.text: I can help you buy loyalty.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Trust? Trust is a commodity, like salt or silk. Everyone has a price; mine is simply higher.
Work for me, and perhaps you’ll earn a share."
Nalia raises a brow. "Opportunity knocks rarely in Sunreach, traveler. If you tire of honest work, return here—I always have use for ambition."

She leans in, voice low and precise.

"Sunreach's prosperity depends on smooth currents—and occasionally, laundering gold too hot for open exchange.
My rivals sniff at my operations. I need someone unconnected to quietly deliver a sealed satchel to a broker in the Crimson Quarter.
The satchel contains coins marked by pirate hands. If intercepted, it will be traced back to Lady Seraphine—and, by extension, me. Fail, and you may find Sunreach’s jails less forgiving than its market.

Discretion and speed, that’s all I require. Are you the reliable sort?"

Option.text: You can rely on me. I’ll deliver the satchel.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Nalia slides a velvet satchel across the counter, her gaze unblinking.

"The Crimson Quarter, northeast docks. Find Broker Saren—give her the password 'Brass Lantern.' She’ll do the rest.
Return with her signed token, and you’ll have earned my trust—and a taste of the Gilded Coin’s favor."

"Broker Saren runs a pawnshop at the edge of the Crimson Quarter. She has more aliases than I have vaults. She’ll know you by the password: 'Brass Lantern.'
Do not mention my name—or Seraphine’s. Fail, and neither of us will save you from Thornwall’s dungeons."

She smirks.

"Coin, of course—plus the goodwill of the Merchant Guild. Complete the job, and I’ll see your account credited handsomely. Loyal contractors may receive... *special* access to guild secrets and under-the-table exchanges.
Fail, and you’ll find your debts mounting—and your enemies multiplying."

Option.text: Very well, I’ll take the job.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Nalia’s eyes narrow, measuring.

"Every coin has a history. Some are best forgotten, some quietly cleansed. The law bends to gold—or breaks. But if you’re too timid, Sunreach may not be the city for you."

Option.text: Maybe I’m not cut out for this.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Nalia arches an eyebrow, clearly amused.

"Curious, are we? Few bother to ask *who* counts the coin—only how much there is. But... I suppose you've earned a glimpse behind the ledger."

Option.text: How did you rise to power in Sunreach?
Who do you trust in the Council?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Nalia smiles faintly, almost nostalgically.

"I was born in the gutter outside Qasaria's western bazaar. By twelve, I ran dice games under temple stairs. By sixteen, I’d loaned half the city's brothel owners their startup gold—and repossessed three of them. Sunreach was a logical next conquest."
She leans in. "You climb with coin, or fall without it."

"I didn't build the Gilded Coin—I *absorbed* it. Their former master vanished one night after a ledger audit. A coincidence, I assure you."
She smiles with gleaming teeth. "When you can balance books with blood, you’re fit to rule this city."

Option.text: You’re more dangerous than you look.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Cutthroat? No. *Clean*. Every debt paid, every price weighed. It's the world that's messy—the numbers are pure."
She shrugs. "Trust steel, but price it first."

"Darius Veynar is useful. He moves gold like a gambler moves dice—fast and without regret. But I fund him."
"Seraphine? She thinks herself untouchable at sea. But her pirates eat my coin. Thornwall pretends to be clean, but I own two of his vices."
She taps the side of her nose. "Everyone has a balance sheet. Even the righteous."

Option.text: You're clearly at the center of it all.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her eyes darken.

"Only fools sleep well in Sunreach. I count the coins before bed—and the knives."
"Still, it's better to hold the debt than owe it."

"Gold is not wealth. It is *leverage*. A sword rusts, but a coin changes hands forever.
With it, you may move hearts, halt armies, and unseat kings. What is loyalty, if not a recurring investment?"
Nalia shrugs. "Cynicism is just experience with the shine rubbed off. You’ll see, in time."

Nalia studies you a moment, then nods.
"Few see that. You may go far in this city."
[You feel your insight deepen.]

Nalia pauses longer than usual.

"Yes... one."
She runs a thumb along her signet ring.
"A girl I raised to be sharper than I ever was. I sent her to Qasaria to broker peace. She returned with ideals—and scars."
"Now she plots against me from the desert sands. I admire her resolve… but I mourn the loss."

Option.text: What would you do, if she returns?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Nalia’s expression softens for just a heartbeat.
"Perhaps. But trust, once broken, trades at steep interest."

Her voice steels.
"I would offer her a seat… or a funeral. The choice is hers. I hope she chooses wisely."
